title-group.article-title: Aeromycoflora of Some Eastern Provinces of Saudi Arabia

article-meta.aff: Department of Biology, Faculty of Science, University of Dammam, P. O. Box 838, Dammam 31113, Saudi Arabia

author-notes.corresp: Ibtisam Mohammed Ababutain, Department of Biology, Faculty of Science, Dammam University, P. O. Box 838, Dammam 31113, Saudi Arabia. Tel. +966569270768, Fax +96638431288, E-Mail dr.king2007@hotmail.com

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2011 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav
permissions.copyright-holder: International Society of the Built Environment

abstract.p: The objective of this study was to estimate the total count of airborne fungi indoors and outdoors in three largest provinces of eastern region of Saudi Arabia. Seasonal variation on the fungi total count and fungi diversity was studied. This study has been carried out by the settling plate technique for a period of 1 year. Samples were collected once in each season. A total of 30 fungi species belonging to 18 genera were isolated. Aspergillus sp. and Cladosporium sp. were the two dominant fungi genera indoors and outdoors. The total fungi count in indoors was less than that of the outdoors. There was seasonal variation in the total count and diversity of the airborne fungi. Fungi diversity was higher in spring indoors and outdoors. Fungi total count in Qatif was the highest then Dammam and then Khobar in indoors, whereas the Dammam was the highest then Khobar and then Qatif in outdoors.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Published statistics in eastern region from the department of health in Saudi Arabia show that number of asthma cases reach 44,781 in 11 provinces. Khobar had the highest percentage among the provinces, which accounted to 13.4%, whereas the rate of asthma prevalence in Dammam was 4%. In general, the statistics showed that there is a ration of more than a million people in Saudi Arabia (13%) suffers from asthma [1]. Consequently, knowledge of anemophilous fungi of a given region is important for the ecological diagnosis and specific treatment of allergic manifestations induced by inhaled allergens.

Several researches consider airborne fungi as the most significant bio-pollutant affecting human health by causing various health hazards, primarily allergies and infectious acute diseases such as lavoltas and upper airway blockage as well as chronic disease such as asthma and bronchitis mycoses [2–16].
Worldwide, there have been studies reported about fungal community both in outdoor and indoor environments [9,17–20].

In Saudi Arabia, few studies were carried out to survey the airborne fungi and none of the studies were carried out in Dammam, Khobar and Qatif [21–27]. Therefore, it is indispensable to survey on concentration, distribution and species of airborne fungi across these different places. Consequently, we can consider this study as the first. Some studies have been done in the Arabian Gulf countries such as Qatar [28] and United Arab Emirates [29].

Objectives of this research were to isolate, identify and compare the total count of airborne fungi in indoors and outdoors in three largest provinces in eastern region and their relation to the spread of asthma in these three provinces. In addition, the seasonal variation on the fungi total count and diversity was also studied.

sec.title: Area of Investigation
sec.p: Three provinces in the eastern region of Saudi Arabia were chosen based on population. First was Dammam, which is considered as the second largest province, second was Khobar, which is considered as the third largest province, and third was Qatif, which is the most important fishing and agricultural area and fourth largest province. This information was collected from the Central Department of Statistics and Information (CDSI) www.cdsi.gov.sa/.

sec.title: Air Sampling
sec.p:
The airborne fungi were isolated through four seasons during 1 year from July 2009 to March 2010 (Table 1); samples were collected once at each season. The cultured plate exposure method [30] was used as follows: in each location, 15 disposable polystyrene Petri dishes (9 cm) containing Potato Dextrose agar (Oxoid, UK) were exposed to the outdoor and indoor environments equally for 30 min at a height between 1 to 1.5 m above the ground between 1 and 2 a.m. A total of 360 Petri dishes were exposed. The exposed Petri dish plates were then incubated at 28 ± 2°C for at least one week and examined twice, once when the fungi colonies were young and again after approximately 7 days. After fungi colonies were counted, these were subcultured on appropriate media for identification. Table 1
The date and the condition where the fungi were collecteda
Season Date of collection Temperature °C Relative humidity % Wind speedKm/h Most weather condition
Min. Max. Min. Max.
Summer 06/07/2009 27.5 42.1 10 29 19 Dusty
Autumn 07/10/2009 21.6 37.2 21 78 28 Plankton
Winter 09/01/2010 09.3 22.5 26 66 32 Partly cloudy
Spring 21/03/2010 15.3 25.5 27 75 30 dusty
a
Obtained by Mohammed Al-Qahtani, Manager of Meteorological Station in Dammam.

sec.title: Identification
sec.p: Identification of isolated fungi up to genera level were carried out by using cultural characteristics and compound microscopic examination at ×400 and ×1000 using the classifications of ref. [31] and the fungi species level were identified in Mycological Centre of Assiut University.

sec.title: Statistical Analysis
sec.p: SPSS Version 15.0 (SPSS. Inc., Evaluation Version), Bivariate Pearson Correlation, was used to find the relationship between the samples.

sec.title: Results and Discussion
sec.p:
The airborne spore near the ground is extremely variable according to time and place. It changes with season and weather. In this study, 360 samples from indoor and outdoor air of eastern region were taken. A total of 462 colonies were isolated from indoors and 1508 colonies from outdoors (Tables 2 and 3). This is in agreement with several research that revealed the indoor fungi counts were less than that of the outdoors [32,33]. However, Penicillium sp. (3.97% indoors and 0.93% outdoors) and yeast (10.17% indoors and 2.12% outdoors) total counts were excluded from those reported (Tables 2 and 3). This may be related to their differences in their needs rather than the rest of other airborne fungi. In addition, fungi count in winter was higher in indoors than in outdoors, which may be related to the use of the heat inside the houses during this season (Table 4). Table 2

The results showed fungi total colony count was higher in spring and lower in summer in all three provinces in indoor and outdoor environments (Tables 2–4). This may be due to the environmental factors such as temperature and humidity (Table 1), which was more suitable for fungi spore distribution in spring than in summer. This finding is in agreement with many studies on airborne fungi, which clarified that high fungi spore concentrations were seen at air temperatures between 15 and 25°C and relative humidity at 60 to 70% [19,34]. On the other hand, fungi spore concentration could be adversely affected by extreme temperature and humidity [35]. Autumn came in second in the fungi spore count; this may be due to the weather conditions, temperature, humidity and the presence of fallen leaves that provide a suitable environment for fungi.

Indoor total colony count in autumn and winter were similar while outdoor total colony count was higher in autumn than in winter (Tables 2–4), which may be due to low temperature outside than inside because of heating to keep the houses warm (Table 1). In general, the result shows that the airborne fungi counts in indoor and outdoor environments were high in, in descending order, spring then autumn then winter then summer (Table 4).

The differences are probably due to the interacting environmental factors, such as climate, vegetation and human activities [18,19,36]. In spring, the vegetation increased substantially in the three provinces which inhabited by several phyllosphere microorganisms such as saprophytic and parasitic fungi [4,37–39], which can be dispersed into the air. Furthermore, several studies considered vegetation is the main contributing factors in fungi outdoor spore concentrations [19,32,36,40]. The result supports this proposal.

In addition, ref. [41] reported that the increase of CO2 concentration could stimulate fungal sporulation, suggesting that levels of the airborne spora could correlate with air pollution; however, an increase in SO2 can reduce airborne fungi concentration.

The result of this study showed that the diversity of the airborne fungi genera in indoors was high in descending order: spring, winter, summer and autumn. Moreover, the fungi concentrations in outdoors were high in descending order: spring, summer, autumn and winter (Table 4). This may be related to their differences in their needs, such as the temperature, humidity, type of vegetation and human activities.

The result revealed that the temperature and humidity factors were more effective than most weather condition and wind speed on the fungi presence in air. This finding is in agreement with ref. [17], which reported that the temperature and humidity were the main factors affecting fungi growth and their release in the atmosphere.

The results showed that the indoor total fungi count was high in Qatif than in Dammam and the latter has a high fungi count than Khobar (Table 2). This is likely due to the difference in the ratio between the population and occupied housing, which was high in Qatif than Dammam and Khobar (Table 5). Table 5
The ratio between population and occupied housing and the ratio between the population and area for the three provinces, and their effect on the total fungi counts in indoor and outdoor environments
Provinces Populationa Occupied housinga Ratio Indoor total fungi count Urban area Km2b Ratio Outhoor total fungi count
Dammam 903,597 149,100 6.06 170 202.040 4.47 529
Khobar 578,500 96,809 5.98 112 65.770 8.80 497
Qatif 524,182 77,637 6.75 180 146.370 3.58 482
a
Central Department of Statistical and Information (CDSI) www.cdsi.gov.sa/. b
Municipality of Dammam - Agency Construction and Projects - General Directorate of Urban Planning.

This is a significant finding, as it is widely recognized that fungi count could decrease in less crowded houses. This finding is supported by several studies [21,23,25] which reported that higher fungi spore concentration were associated with crowded places. In addition, outdoor study showed Qatif had the lowest total fungi count than Dammam and Khobar, which may be related to the lowest ratio between the population and urban area whereas Khobar had a lower fungi total count than Dammam, although it is more crowded in Khobar and this could be related to other factor which will need further investigation (Table 3, 5).

Statistical analysis showed significant correlations between the fungi total count indoors in all seasons and in the three provinces with the exception of Dammam and Khobar in summer, and Khobar and Qatif in winter. Outdoor fungi total counts showed significant correlations in all seasons and three provinces.

There was significant correlation between indoor and outdoor total counts. Excluding that, there was no significant correlation between, summer indoors and spring in indoor and outdoor environments, winter outdoors and spring outdoor total counts. In addition, there was significant difference between indoor and outdoor total counts in all seasons in all provinces. Excluding that, there was no significant difference between fungi total counts in Dammam and Khobar in summer indoors only.

The result revealed high fungi diversity in the indoor and outdoor air. Since the fungi spores where isolated belonged to three divisions. Zygomycota represented by two fungi, division Ascomycota represented by 11 fungi plus yeast and Deuteromycota represented by 15 fungi (Tables 2 and 3). This is an important finding, which is in agreement with ref. [32], which reported that the composition of indoor airborne fungi should reflect the diversity of outdoor airborne fungi, but at lower concentrations. In addition, all three divisions have the greatest number of well-known causative fungi of allergic symptoms [2–8,10,11,13,14,42]. This may explain the reason for the spread of allergic manifestations in eastern region especially in Khobar.

Results have shown that Aspergillus sp. and Cladosporium sp. were the two dominant fungi genera in indoor and outdoor environments. Aspergillus sp. represented by nine species (30.09% indoors and 34.68% outdoors) and Cladosporium sp. represented by two species (22.73% indoors and 22.55% outdoors). Then Alternaria sp. (7.43% outdoors and 4.99% indoors), which was represented by two species Al. alternate and Al. solani. Yeast was higher in indoors (10.17%) than outdoors (2.12%). In addition were several fungi genera like Penicillium sp., Acremonium sp., Scopulariopsis brevicaulis, Ulocladium atrum, Stemphylium sp., Rhizoctonia sp., Myrothecium verrucaria, Drechslera australiensis, Fusarium sp., Epicoccum sp., Curvularia eragrostidis, Pleospora infectoria, Nigrospora sp., Rhizopus sp. and muocar sp., which were isolated in different concentrations in indoor and outdoor locations. Most of these fungi were isolated by many researchers in indoor and outdoor environments but in different concentrations [9,17–25]. The genus Myrothecium was first isolated, as most abundant spore, in indoor air as reported in ref. [43].

Several researchers considered Aspergillus sp., Cladosporium sp., Alternaria sp., Penicillium sp., Ulocladium sp., Fusarium sp., Nigrospora sp. and Acremonium sp. the most common allergenic genera around the world [4,9,20,42,44–47]. Therefore, fungal allergic diseases can be prevented by studying the distribution and the spreading of airborne fungi. In addition, airborne fungi spores could deteriorate indoor air quality [48,49].

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: In general, this study clearly demonstrated that fungi total count outdoors was higher than in indoors. Also, higher indoor levels of fungi spores were not associated with high levels found outdoors. Fungi total count and diversity was affected significantly according to the seasons. Increasing allergies in the spring may be associated with the increasing fungi total counts. There was a positive relationship between the fungi total count indoors and crowded houses, but this relationship was unclear in outdoor study. Measuring the level of gases (CO2, SO2) may have a benefit in clarifying the relationship between them.

ack.title: Acknowledgment
ack.p: The author would like to thank Mr. Mohammed Al-Qahtani, Manager of Meterological Station in Dammam for his cooperation. I am thankful to Prof. Moubasher AH, Prof. Aida Al-Zawahiri, Prof. Moharram and Dr.Hassan M. Assiut University for their help in fungi species identification.
